title: The Futurists - EPS_278: Dealing with High Volatility with Donna Dupont

rawLines.text: [Music]
hey there welcome back to the futurist
I'm Rob Turk and this week I'm flying
solo because Brett King is out there
barnstorming around the world as he
always is bringing the vision and ideas
of the future to audiences around the
world that's kind of our mission here we
want to help more people think about the
future and Brett is tireless in his
efforts to do so um this week I've been
thinking all about emergencies I've been
thinking about uh some of the strange
possibilities that may lie in the future
it's no coincidence it's no happy
accident that I'm thinking about that um
we have had a week of strange
announcements from the incoming in
Administration in the United States uh
the new president is starting to appoint
his cabinet and in almost every case the
people he's appointing are people who
stand for and vigorously oppose um the
policies and the organizations that
they're going to be leading so he's
actually putting together not a cabinet
not a team of rals as we've heard in the
past about other presidents but it's a
team of loyalists uh who collectively
are going to be kind of wrecking bom and
that brought to mind uh some of the past
some of the moments from the past for me
I've been thinking about how
ill-prepared um president Trump was the
last time he was in office and how that
led to catastrophes in the United States
and elsewhere in the world uh so
planning matters foresight matters and
it makes makes a very important
difference who you select to do the
planning and forecasting
and I thought in the context of that it
would be helpful for our audience to
hear from someone who is a deep expert
in the subject of foresight and planning
and strategy Our Guest today is Donna
Dupont she's the founder and chief
strategist of foresight and design at
purple Compass which is an advisory
based in Canada and she's also a
principal at the School of International
Futures and Donna focuses on public
safety and emergency preparedness and
emergency response
and so I guess um I can do no better
service to our listeners than to find
someone who's an expert in these
subjects because I think we're all going
to need to develop some expertise in
Emergency Management in just a couple
months um when this clown car of cabinet
starts to take office well welcome to
the futur is Donna it's a great pleasure
to have you here thank you for joining
our
show thank you for the invitation Rob um
so I thought what we might do to begin
with is uh learn a little bit more about
you so you work at purple Compass you
actually started purple Compass tell me
tell me about the mission of that
organization yeah um it's a good
question so I started purple Compass six
years ago actually seven now just turned
seven and originally the mission was to
support those that were working in
public or private sector who wanted to
build Futures thinking within their
organization and and so that's where it
started and then in the last seven years
I've had an opportunity to work on
projects all over the world supporting
organizations and collaborating with a
lot of different um
AES you know supporting um you know a
lot of work
in mostly defense and security but
that's been broadening out in terms of
security meaning um Health security and
and different climate Security emergency
management and even International
Development so all of these agencies are
really trying to cultivate this Futures
mind mindset and so I've been working on
a various projects around the world to
help them build that internal capacity
and capability and you've done that for
provincial governments in Canada and and
the national government in Canada but
you've also worked with I know for
instance uh European agencies as well is
that right I have yes I have so I I
definitely have partnered with the
School of International futures um it
was more um being part of their Network
where I acted as a principal on a
variety of projects for them to help
bring in the for but because of my
background in security it allowed me to
explore those really complex topics
within those projects and some of the
things you've talked about you you've
you've got expertise in public health um
I would imagine that extends to
pandemics and infectious disease because
that's a big Focus for public health but
you've also worked with um in the UK
you've worked on the future of policing
and you've also done work with mines
like mining as is that
right yes yes there's a lot there so um
definitely I have a background in
provincial government I used to work um
as a public servant and so yes I have a
very strong Health background both
clinically in the field and then in
government and in public health
specifically in Emergency Management
responding to a variety of emergencies
like uh wildfires floods but also health
related emergencies like infectious
dises outbreaks and
pandemics um that's been a
previous but yes now within foresight
and design and and the work I've been
doing the last seven years it's it's
been much more broader in terms of
working with organizations at the
national and international level and
really helping with some of these big
challenges complex Global challenges for
organizations and so it's it's a very
different uh perspective in seeing
what's happening at that level
and international level you're talking
about moving really big uh Machinery
like the these are Big organizations and
they represent huge populations how
difficult is it to get consensus is that
a big part of your job to build
consensus on what to
do so it's a process it's um so when you
are working with organizations that want
to explore futures or use Futures in
their you know in the work that they do
it's a process of understanding the
landscape right and it's a process of
engaging different people so it's so
understanding the landscape means you
know taking a look at some of the
information you have what do we know in
terms of the evidence and the system and
working with experts to say okay what's
changing in the system and then starting
to then build some sort of have sense
making around what's happening in the
system and then engaging other people
broadly in terms of having strategic
conversations around specific points in
the system where you there's a potential
for things to escalate where we're
seeing aot of challenges where there's
pressures for the organization those are
opportunities to go much deeper and let
me ask you a little bit about that so so
one of the things you're trying to do
what I'm hearing you say is you're
trying to solicit opinions and
perspectives from many different let's
say stakeholders people who have an
opinion um and yet I would imagine in a
big complex organization there are
differing opinions sometimes probably
clashing uh opinions about what to do or
what the nature of the problem is how do
you avoid an opinion War how do you
avoid a situation where you have two
people who have equal Authority or equal
expertise who fundamentally disagree
about what the issue is or what the
problem they're facing might be or what
the solution might be how do you manage
that as an outside
facilitator yeah that's a really good
question it's it's typically in the
setup of whatever type of Workshop that
we are
engaging and it's about setting some
ground rules around how we communicate
in that particular Workshop because you
will have people with different
perspectives and very strong
perspectives but you want to create a
safe a psychologically safe space to
have these conversations and to really
look at the tension points around that
and have dialogue about okay if it's
it's not so much what's you know which
one is right but sometimes you have to
transcend a lot of these contradictions
or different opinions and so it's
creating a safe space for that type of
dialogue to have those kind of
conversations and to see what new
insights you can generate around what it
means for the future and that's part of
the work it's it's not predicting the
future I as as a person who works in the
professional foresight in future space I
don't predict the future what we do is
in this space is we understand
uncertainty and change and we work with
it in a very focused and um intentional
way to advance dialogue right and then
from that dialogue we have new insights
and it's mining those new insights that
can shape all kinds of new decisions for
the future sure I get that and and
that's of course that's the goal is to
get to the insights but we live in a
world where um the leaders of
organizations are often people who are
rewarded in their career and get career
advancement by being very decisive about
uh by by making decisions even when they
don't have the 100% of the information
and that type of personality is often
impatient with too much process and
often feels like it can leap to the
solution uh it can skip over the problem
definition phase because they already
know what to do and what I found in my
own work uh when I do workshops like
this with organizations whether they're
um public sector or private sector is
that it's often the leaders who create
the um unproductive Dynamics in a
workshop setting or in a um in a
inperson setting because first of all
because of the hierarchy they speak with
greater Authority than others in the
room but then secondly because of the
what I just described uh they have a
kind of history of track record of being
rewarded for being very decisive very
quickly um but in the process you're
talking about it's kind of delicate
right in the beginning you want to
solicit a lot of different opinions you
want to get hear from everybody in the
organization top bottom side out in the
periphery and so forth U because you
might new information there and
sometimes those executive leaders are
impatient with that process so tell me a
little bit about that if you've had an
experience like that how have you
managed through
that that's a really great question
because you are right sometimes leaders
need to make decisions uh you know
immediately in the short term with very
little information and that's true and
uh but foresight is not um foresight is
a longer longer process and so
usually when an organization wants to
engage in this type of thinking the
leadership is supporting more of a
longer term process so they understand
an agreement up front with them you say
how it's going to work and here's what
you got to do and you got to restrain
the impulse and and let other people
talk yeah well they understand that this
is going to be probably a minimum a
six-month type of Engagement Pro process
right and and you'll have different
types of activities that gradually build
on each other to advance in insights for
Action so you're right so and you want
to set the tone right from the beginning
so I work with my clients and I help
them build the internal you know
capabilities to kind of manage those
Dynamics you know within the
organization so it's setting the
foundations of this is what this
Workshop is about the
expectations this is how we have to
flatten the power structures so we want
to hear from everyone want to engage
external um maybe external key external
stakeholders and get their perspective
and input so you're setting the
foundation upfront and if you are having
challenges with that it does compromise
the ability to do good foresight work
yeah for sure no I get that get that
basically they're not going to get what
they paid for if they interrupt and
dominate the
session and people feel safe to express
right if they disagree for fear of being
judged or fear that it might impact
their their their job now there're
probably people who are not in the room
when you're doing that kind of work uh
how do you solicit their input how do
you make sure that the views of the
people out in the field or in the
periphery uh how do they how do they get
their views represented in the session
yeah it's a good question so typically
before you get into a strategic
conversation Series where you're doing
all kinds of activities including
scenarios you're there's an upfront
piece as I mentioned around
understanding the landscape and
sometimes as part of that it's not just
scanning for information and looking at
Trends and emerging issues but we also
interview experts and so you'll probably
want to be very clear about who the
experts are that you really want some
deeper knowledge and perspective and
insights and it's not just experts that
can tell you the trends you want experts
that are in that system that know that
world really well and they can tell you
what's Chang Ching what are things that
are emerging what are some of those weak
signals of
change know that we can see that are
happening we don't know how they're
going to evolve but we know it's a shift
what are those emerging issues can
things potentially escalate so you
really want to get those experts and you
want to know get different perspectives
so you can do that through interviews
and then bring those insights into um a
strategic conversation series and have a
variety of different stakeholders work
with that knowledge now here in the
United States um and actually around the
world this is a year of Elections right
so half the population of the planet
voted in a national election this year
we've seen a wave of um resistance uh
against uh you know I guess opposition
to the ruling party whatever party was
in power in almost every country in the
world has either lost share of Voters or
they actually been turned out of office
so it's not just a phenomenon that
happened in the US recently but it's
actually happened around the world this
year uh so there's a sort of rising tide
of people are pushing back some of
that's economic people are pushing back
against inflation and prices and they're
just punishing whichever part's in
office but there's a second Trend and I
think it's relevant to what you just
said the second trend is that there's
also a rising tide of resistance to top-
down hierarchy and so-called experts uh
the idea that you know we're going to
let the experts make the decision or
make the recommendation and uh the
bureaucracy is going to defer to outside
experts what we start to see is these
populist movements and they're all over
the world
populist movements reject that expert
idea um now that's not always great
because the sometimes those populist
movements unleash Anarchy you know they
don't know uh and um and people rebel
against it what I'm thinking about right
now as I say that as an example for our
listeners is um during the pandemic
around the world we saw resistance to
wearing a mask a mask was a simple
precaution the main benefit of the Mask
was that you didn't sneeze on somebody
else or cough on somebody else so it
minimized the amount of you know um uh
spreading of the disease that way uh it
would not save you of course uh from
getting an infection that's true but
around the world we saw people resist
that even though experts around the
world like look this is a simple
precaution that everyone can take and if
we all do it it'll help a little bit
people resisted it they also resisted
taking a vaccine uh and there were all
sorts of crazy conspiracy theories about
vaccines people who had absolutely no
idea what they're talking about people
with no understanding of infectious
disease and no understanding of vaccines
were making wild claims like the vaccine
contains microchip that's going to
somehow track you or something these are
people who don't understand radio
technology they don't understand what
microchips are or how you do a power
supply for electronics they were
literally just spouting nonsense but
these ideas gained a great deal of
traction and I think that's one of the
problems that we have today in media uh
the democratization of media tools has
made it possible for people with
crackpot ideas to spread those ideas
around the world very quickly and now
the crazy people can find each other all
the crazy people who believe that stuff
can find each other and connect um and
so you start to see that that emerges as
a voice or that emerges as you know a
point of view right and our tendency
people like you and me our tendency is
to try to gather all views right we want
to make sure everybody's represented
because we think it's important to
include all the perspectives that's how
you get byy in that's how you build
consensus but when you invite the views
of crack populists who have no
fundamental understanding of the
Dynamics at work here no history no
expertise you're actually inviting chaos
into the room because you have a group
of people that aren't going to respect
the knowledge or wisdom
uh the many years of expertise that are
represented in the room uh how do you
handle that phenomenon by the way this
is something I struggle with in my own
work uh this is a constant challenge
wherever I work in the world so go ahead
talk about that one I know I'm throwing
you curveballs here today but it's kind
of a fun conversation for me that is a
wild curveball but it's a really
important question
because you're right like when um you're
right you can't ignore this when you're
doing foresight work because a lot of
times when we're looking at scanning
we're not just looking at like the
geopolitics or the emergencies or the
economics or the tech because a lot of
times people focus on technology and all
of that and that's important but you
have to look at the social dimensions of
it what's happening in the culture and
and how they're responding to the shifts
happening geopolitically or
economically and the rate of change
that's happening and the pressure it's
putting on people and so how we look at
it within a foresight project is that we
look at what's happening
from a social Dynamic perspective where
are things escalating where are their
potential for conflicts or where are the
conflicts happening and trying to
understand that pattern within the
system what's driving that because
that's also very much deeply in systems
thinking so I do a lot of combination of
systems analysis with anticipatory
thinking and Futures so when I look at
that kind of social um Dynamic it's
important to see what is that that Loop
that vicious feedback loop that's
happening there what's driving it you
know and is there something that we can
do to slow down the speed of growth or
can we do something to balance it out so
it actually by understanding and going
deeper into that Dynamic you can start
ask very interesting questions about the
system and which way it's going how to
balance it and if it were to really be
disruptive what does that mean for the
organization the system what are those
cascading
consequences it seems to me that that's
a necessary step just for acceptance
alone you know in other words you might
um develop a great strategy you might
develop a series of tactics that will
get you to achieve that strategy uh
that'll get you to the right place but
all that Strate and tactics is
meaningless if you can't get the
population to go along with you and I
think this is one of the places where
our bureaucrats tend to fail they're a
little tedea when it comes to talking to
people of course politicians are not
toned deaf they understand it um and if
the populace is you know resistant to it
they're going to adopt that very quickly
and then that puts great pressure on the
bureaucrats and I see that at least in
this country I see that quite frequently
where you've got a disconnect between
what we call inside the Beltway you know
the people that run the national
government that staff the national
government and then the politicians who
represent all the all the folks in the
rest of the country sometimes those
politicians are echoing the populist
perspectives and I think it's very
difficult very very very very difficult
for a bureaucrat who's used to being
listened to by virtue the fact that
they've done the job for a long time
they know the subject matter and they
have some degree of expertise but they
may lack the Charisma to communicate
that message in a way that it'll be
accepted by a large number of people uh
so that's a failure of leadership
and so in some respects I think what
you're working on and the kind of work
you do it's it's not just about helping
develop the muscle of foresight and
planning and strategic thinking there's
another set of muscles you're developing
which are communication tools and
leadership ability how does a strategy
and planning dovetail with leadership
how how should our leaders approach the
subject of
strategy it's a good
question so thanks when you're looking
that's what we do on this show is ask
you yeah I have to think about this one
but but you have to think about the
environment we're in right now we're in
a very you know volatile type of
environment there's a lot of changes
happening everywhere it's very complex
there's a lot of uncertainty and it's
creating a lot of discomfort for people
a lot of anxiety and fear so leaders
need to understand this um and they need
to when they're putting together their
strategies
first of all they need to to understand
and to reflect on whether their
strategies are are reflected are they
reflective of the needs of those that
they're serving for example there's an
empathy element to this in terms of
understanding the needs of different
people perspectives maybe populations
and and what they fundamentally need so
seeing it through there you know as best
as you can kind of seeing it through
them their lens how they might see
things perceive things what they need to
feel secure to feel like there's a
future to feel hope you know you need to
kind of look at it from their
perspective especially when you're
cultivating and you're designing
whatever strategy but also in the
communication of it how are you
connecting with people how are you
resonating with things that matter to
them this is very important right
absolutely right look during the
pandemic I I dealt with uh a group here
in California um local Business Leaders
and we had a complete shutdown of
business uh it was it was killing small
businesses they couldn't afford to keep
paying their rent and so on um and I
talked to Kathleen Ferrero who was the
head epidemiologist for the County of
Los Angeles which represents millions of
people it's a very big area here in
California um and I said look you know
what the Business Leaders want to know
is what what measures can we take to
stay open what can we do to keep our
doors open can you give some guidance on
that it can't just be a blanket like
Clos the close the store because the
economy is going to collapse if you
continue doing that and she said it's
not my responsibility to tell them what
to do to manage the business I'm not
responsible for the economic well being
I'm responsible for the public health
and I'm telling you right now we're
going to keep the place Clos I was
really stunned at the um complete lack
of empathy and complete lack of
understanding and the unwillingness to
even contemplate those perspectives from
the people who pay her salary I was
really stunned by that and of course it
gave me great insight into the massive
level of resentment towards the state
government here uh you know where I'm a
huge believer in public safety and of
course I comply with all those uh
recommendations because I don't want to
get sick like to me it makes perfect
sense to do those things but I
understood suddenly I was like oh wow
this is a government that has a
disconnect with the population right the
regular citizens here they are they have
a need it's not being heard they're
being told to do something that you know
inherently doesn't make sense and
doesn't feel right to them and no one's
making a good explanation no one's
attempting to like explain why that's
going to serve them better or how
they're going to come out with a better
outcome okay listen uh really important
okay go ahead ahead if that's important
I want to hear all about it go oh it's
so important because what you're saying
here is that that kind of behavior of
not actually thinking from the
perspective of you know those that are
being impacted by what policies or you
know that are or strategies that are
being implemented what's happening is
people are having a distrust in the
system you know and and and so they
don't feel confident they don't feel
heard they don't feel valued and they're
disconnecting and they just don't want
to listen I think this this this Global
phenomenon populism people are like I
don't trust the government I don't trust
the experts and so on okay let me do
this before we go to a break what we
love to do is get to know our guests a
little bit more and so we ask a series
of short questions so these can be like
a one onew answer a very short answer
one sentence answer um I'm going to ask
you a few questions about how you came
to think about the future and so this is
the lightning
round um here we go the first question
in the lightning round for Donna
Dupont tell me about a futurist who has
impressed you or shaped your perspective
about the future someone who's inspired
you wow this is going to be hard because
I studied futur thinking and I studied a
lot of different methodology so um
someone who shaped my perspective of the
future I would have to say that
um it would be Alvin Toffler oh great
author of Future Shock yeah great still
relevant today so relevant I actually re
was rereading that book a couple years
ago and I was like yes yes like this is
this is actually what's happening today
the acceler ation and the you know
questioning whether people can adapt to
the change and what happens if we have
to adapt too quickly what does that do
to a society you know it's really
relevant if people haven't heard haven't
listened to Future so haven't read
Future Shock the book's 50 years old but
it's such a worthwhile read he was on it
he he saw the long-term trends okay next
question um what was your first
experience or exposure to science
fiction what's the first science fiction
show or book or story that you
read yeah I would say the first book
science fiction book that really
resonated with me where I really felt
something was the the cacal for lioz oh
great it's a really old book but I
remember reading it when I was like 12
and I remember just like just being so
you know I was just so immersed in the
story of you know of this it was very
dystopian very dark but there this you
know beam of light towards the future
and hope and trying to navigate you know
for some meaning and Truth in the world
and and I think that just really
inspired me yeah the the grocery the
grocery list from the past they created
a whole kind of like you know belief
system and and as people are trying to
rebuild the future wow great fun okay
folks we're listening to Donna Dupont uh
she's an expert in foresight and
strategic thinking and um we are going
to come back in a moment after this
break to talk about some of the
implications of uh some of the decisions
are being made right now uh for the
future you're listening to the futurist
I'm Rob Turk we'll be back in just a
minute okay welcome back to the futurist
I'm Rob TK this week I'm flying solo
without Brett King because he's over in
the Middle East again barnstorming
around the world teaching people about
the future my guest is Donna Dupont and
Donna is an expert in helping
organizations develop and cultivate a
better understanding in the future and
since that's what we like to do in this
show she's the perfect guest for the
show you know Donna as we were talking
about your Broad expertise in the public
sector in the military and defense crime
fighting um even in mining and other
complex operations what was on my mind
the whole time is this one question I
want to hit you with now which is this
what should we be worried about what are
the impending crises of the future that
we should all be concerned
about so these days where a lot of my
attention is focused is on climate
security so climate change and security
because it has such it it really applies
to everyone we're all living you know in
this environment and there's a lot of
changes happening in the environment and
a lot of times we're not necessarily
paying attention because sometimes that
information is so scientific it's hard
to apply in terms of what it means to my
day-to-day life um but we are seeing a
lot of changes happening um at the
global level and it's being manifested
as emergencies or disasters right right
and so we're seeing an increase of that
around the world and and that's that's
very concerning because that will create
a lot
of additional vulnerability within the
system if people are not able to to cope
with these types of response to
emergencies or recover yeah we have a
good example of that right now in the US
you know we have the Federal Emergency
Management um agency which has depleted
its budget for responding to uh climate
emergencies particularly extreme weather
emergencies we just saw that happened
with the series of huge hurricanes that
hit the southeast um you know
unprecedented levels of damage I think
Brett quoted a figure of $130 billion of
damage that's been incurred so that's
completely overwhelming for that agency
and I guess the point there is simple if
uh if we continue to heat up the climate
and continue to pump out carbon into the
at atmosphere we're going to get more of
that extreme weather not less uh so we
seem to be doing exactly the wrong
Behavior if we want to mitigate that
crisis what should we be
doing
so well first of all I think that it's
really important to have a lot more
awareness of what's happening within the
environment so and that means for people
too at the local level because as you
said the environment's changing and and
the likelihood of a lot more extreme
weather events is pretty plausible right
that we're going to see that it's going
to look different in different parts of
the world depending on where you live if
you're near a coastline you know or if
you're you know in another part of the
country or another part of the world so
it really depends on but I think what we
need to be doing as Citizens you know is
looking at what this means in terms of
where I live so how do I protect my home
at a personal level how do I stay safe
in my community and and thinking about
building internal or
resilience at the personal community and
then your organizational level too
because organizations need to think
about how is this changing climate
affecting you know my day-to-day
business right sure sure hang on help me
understand help me understand something
I'm sorry so I'm sorry to crash in but
when you say that I'm thinking of our
audience right now there's somebody
who's listening who's thinking well what
can I do to stop climate change what can
I do you know perhaps they're listening
in their car as they drive to work right
so uh you know they can pack an
emergency kit I suppose in case there's
an earthquake or a gigantic storm right
so you can you can take that precaution
you make sure you have Provisions to
protect your family and feed your family
at your home um but what can an
individual do to prevent a wildfire or
to prevent a flood is there anything
they can realistically do I think
there's a sense of helplessness there
right we're told to be prepared we're
told to be resilient but what is the
actual thing that we can do well when
you talk about pre prevention of an
actual Wildfire or prevention of a flood
I think for the
individual that's usually not their role
is to prevent the actual Hazard and
sometimes we don't we can't prevent the
hazard like it's the conditions within
